title: How to Use Pandoc Filters for Advanced Customisation of Your R Markdown Documents
description: In a package I'm developing, I had a problem around highlighting text in LaTeX and HTML output. The solution was to use **pandoc filters** for complete control over the final document. Here's a guide to writing such filters when R Markdown ain't got what you need.

title: How to Create New Chunk Options in R Markdown
description: What to do when the chunk options you need to get R Markdown to do what you want is missing? You create the ones you need. It is incredibly useful to be able to do so --- unfortunately it can also be tricky to figure out how. Here's a quick guide.

title: How to Build Safari App Extensions
description: Apple is deprecating traditional Safari Extensions in favor of 'Safari App Extensions' which have to be built using Xcode. However, I couldn't find any tutorials walking through a basic example of how to build extensions for Safari in this way, and it was therefore a slow and painful learning process when I wanted to convert a simple extension for Facebook into a Safari App Extension. Here's a tutorial to help others.

title: R packages for CHI papers with R Markdown
description: In a previous blog post, I detailed at length the nitty-gritty of how one might take the ACM Master Article LaTeX templates and get them to play nicely with R Markdown. To make it super easy in practice, I created two R packages which supply easy-to-use R Markdown templates in RStudio for CHI Proceedings and CHI Extended Abstracts.

title: How to Write ACM Articles with R Markdown
description: I love R Markdown, but struggled for hours and hours to get it to play nicely with arbitrary LaTeX templates, especially for submissions to the ACM CHI conference. I cracked it in the end (I think). Here's a tutorial explaining how to write CHI articles in R Markdown using ACM's new article template.

title: Ulysses in Cyberspace
description: Tech companies compete to make devices that do more faster, and with less effort. Yet an entire market has emerged for apps that remove functionality from laptops and smartphones, punish people for using Facebook when they shouldn’t, or provide easy ways to visualise how much they use their devices. Do the new anti-distraction tools actually change behaviour, and what could minimally-distracting design for always-connected devices look like?

title: Making Statistics Make Sense
description: For students who struggle with learning statistics, or for researchers who aren’t themselves statisticians, our obscure vocabulary makes understanding and remembering concepts unnecessarily difficult. It increases the number of terms to learn and puts a smokescreen over the relationship between tests. Reforming our statistics vocabulary should make statistics quicker to learn, more transparent to understand, and easier to use.

title: Digging Science Out of a Hole: The Reproducibility Index
description: Science is in trouble. We find ourselves with a mess of publications in which true findings are scattered among false positives. An unacceptably wide range of claims can be made to seem legitimate by cherrypicking the literature. We urgently need a transparent metric for the level of confidence to have in specific findings - we urgently need a 'Reproducibility Index'.
